column4: I'm thinking of trying to learn programming, most likely with C/++ and Java. Does anyone have any suggestions for what to install? (Keep in mind the main purpose of this is to LEARN to program.)
if you want to learn how to program, then you should learn python
Why's that?
it's very useful on linux, and easier to learn
wait a few more seconds and i'll give you an online tutorial my teacher wrote
The ease of learning a language has no impact on me. If I want to, I can learn it regardless.
Also, I'm looking for what to install. IDE, compiler, documentation...
for python, install idle and python2.4, it's an interpreted language so it doesn't need to be compiled
Is the Python documentation installable, or is it online?
http://www.ibiblio.org/obp/thinkCSpy/
it's most certaintly online, and there probably is documentation that's installable
if you learn python first, you'll be able to learn other languages with even more ease, :)
The problem with that is that once I were to learn Python, if I went on to learn other languages, I'd still need to know what compilers/editors/documentation to install.
that's not too hard to find out, the harder part is learning how to program
there's how to think like a computer scientist books for c++ and java, though
I'm not your ordinary computer geek. I find learning to program easier than figuring out what I need to program.
There are like four versions of both gcc and g++ in my package list. Not having programmed before, I don't know which one I would want.
any of them would compile your program, most likely :p
whichever one's name makes you feel the happiest :p
But there would usually be a suggested one over the others.
I've used wallpapoz before, but I wanted to see if it (or an alternative) was readily available before getting it.
